did i answer ur question or you need more explanation?

no, it doesnt have to have 2 rotors on top. The heli can fly that way with 3 or 4 rotors blades however i think 2 rotor blades seem to be most efficient ( i think) and most manufactrere sell those blades in pair.

on a real helicopter, the gyro is the human pilot and he can only act that fast. So let;s say we made a computer to correct the tail in place of the pilot, i dont think the rotor shaft, main body or the blades can handle the stress during the transition from upright to inverted because a real helicopter weights several thousand lbs while the RC heli only weighs about 10-15 lbs.

on a real helicopter however, i think the swash plate can only travel in one direction ( positive) and it relies on gravity to go down if a real helicopter to flip inverted, it will not have the negative pitch to keep it hovering. One more thing, on RC helicopter tail correction is made by a gyro , which taking thousand or million of inputs to correct the rail from spining by changing the pitch of the tail rotor.

However, there is a crucial different on the swash plate design, On rc helicopter, the swash plate can travel in the postive ( up ) and negative ( down ) equally. Normally, on RC helicopter, the pitch of the blade can travel from -13 to 0 to +13 degree of pitch so when the heli is upside down, the RC pilote can apply negative pitch to keep the heli hovers upside down.

yes, both have body and airframe, main rotor and tail rotor but there is a huge diffrent in term of rotor design. Think about what makes the real helicopter goes straight up. The pilot increase the pitch in the positive direction and the helicopter goes up. It;s the same with RC helicopter , increas positive pitch the rc helicopter goes up

3) the airframe of the helicopter will disintegrate as soon as being thrown around like that. 4)RC helicopter has equal pitch travel meaning the blade can have the same degree in positive and negative direction but most real helicopter has more positive than negative. Positive to go up and negative to go down.

on paper, real helicopter can do anything this rc helicopter can do but in real life there are several limitation. 1) Human is the first because during those maneuvers, the helicopter experiences some extreme g force atleast 20G and the human body cant sustain that. 2) power, real helicopter can not have enough power to weight ratio to throw it around like that. That rc helicopter can produce somewhere 9-13 HP and weighs around 6-7 lbs fully loaded.

Those who think this is fake look up 3d RC helicopter flight.  The reason real helicopters can't do this is that they're too heavy and they can't handle the stresses.  Piloted helicopters are not set up for negative collective required for inverted flight as well.  When you see them roll or loop the pilot will go to zero collective as the machine inverts and apply positive collective as it comes out of the roll/loop.  In short the big machines just are not built for it, nor are the pilots.

@christiantillman84  Chuck Aaron's RedBull BO-105 cannot "fly" upside down. It can flip and roll, however it is unable to sustain inverted flight. The minimum pitch angle of the blades on that BO-105 is only 0°. We need negative pitch to fly inverted.

The rotor is spinning in the same direction all the time. Helicopters have a mechanical system that changes the angle of the rotor blades. When the blade is horizontal, there's no lift so this allows the choppa to stay on the ground while the blades are spinning fast. Some rc helicopters can turn the blades over horizontal so that the blades are pushing air up instead of down. This allows it to fly upside down. As far as I know there's not a single real heli that'd could do this.

@PureZOOKS In the future, anything is possible. But for right now, they're just not there yet. But in the meantime, you might have a look at Chuck Aaron's BO-105 (the Redbull helicopter) that does loops & rolls & stuff. Videos are all over youtube of that one. It can flip, and roll, but is incapable of sustained inverted flight. The blades can only go to 0° pitch inverted.

@stalker7d7 Fuel does indeed slosh around, but not so much that it's a huge problem. But if air does get in through the pick up line, it can cause a lean run, which leads to heat, which leads to a cooked engine. Not good. We use one of two way to get around that. One is a specialized porous clunk which reduces the possibility for air bubbles getting in, the other way (which we don't see much anymore) are header tanks, which is a small, secondary tank mounted alongside the main tank.

The basic physics is rather simple really. The blades have a variable pitch; they can change their angle of attack (AoA) while airborne.  This allows the helicopter to fly upside down. A negative AoA while upright is a positive AoA when the inverted.

The blades definitely DO NOT change their direction of motion in the air, it takes way too much energy to reverse their motion, besides helicopter blades are often designed for maximum aerodynamic efficiency in a single fixed direction of rotation.
